gw.api.database

Class LazyJoinTable<T extends Bean>

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.database.LazyJoinTable<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of Bean for the BaseQuery or BaseTable

    public class LazyJoinTable<T extends Bean>
extends java.lang.Object
    This class allows a "lazy join" between a base query and a potential table to join to. The join is lazy in that it will not actually add the join to the query unless the joinIfNecessary() method is called. This is intended to be used by Search Criterias that build up complicated joins between multiple entities, but may not want all those tables joined to the base query unless a parameter specified on the joined table is actually used. A LazyJoinTable can connect to either an existing Query, in which case the constructor using a Query should be used; or to another LazyJoinTable, which uses its own constructor. Linked LazyJoinTables will load themselves and any required parents to joinIfNecessary to a base query. Example:

    Query query = Query.make(PolicyPeriod)}
    LazyJoinTable policyTable = new LazyJoinTable(query, PolicyPeriod.POLICY_PROP.get())
    LazyJoinTable accountTable = new LazyJoinTable(policyTable, Policy.ACCOUNT_PROP.get())
    LazyJoinTable jobTable = new LazyJoinTable(query, PolicyPeriod.JOB_PROP.get())

    In the example above we use valid joins to define the relationship between each additional table and chain back to the original PolicyPeriod query. Only if we later call joinIfNecessary() on one of the LazyLoadTables will it and any LazyLoadTable parents be actually added to the query.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      LazyJoinTable(LazyJoinTable<T> baseTable, ILinkPropertyInfo joinColumn)
      Creates a LazyJoinTable that will join to the given LazyJoinTable.
      LazyJoinTable(Query<T> baseQuery, ILinkPropertyInfo joinColumn)
      Creates a LazyJoinTable that will join to the given baseQuery.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Table<T> joinIfNecessary()
      When called this will check to see if joinIfNecessary has already been invoked, and if it has it will use the previously created Table created from invoking that join.

    • Constructor Detail

      • LazyJoinTable

        public LazyJoinTable(Query<T> baseQuery,
                     ILinkPropertyInfo joinColumn)
        Creates a LazyJoinTable that will join to the given baseQuery. Only creates the join statement if joinIfNecessary() is called, and then only creates the join for the first call to joinIfNecessary() - subsequent calls will use the same joined table.
        Parameters:
        baseQuery - the Query to potentially join to
        joinColumn - the column on the entity type of baseQuery to use when creating the join

      • LazyJoinTable

        public LazyJoinTable(LazyJoinTable<T> baseTable,
                     ILinkPropertyInfo joinColumn)
        Creates a LazyJoinTable that will join to the given LazyJoinTable. Only creates the join statement if joinIfNecessary() is called, which will also then call joinIfNecessary() on the base LazyJoinTable. This will eventually chain back to the original Query.
        Parameters:
        baseTable - the LazyJoinTable to potentially join to
        joinColumn - the column on the entity type of baseTable to use when creating the join

    • Method Detail

      • joinIfNecessary

        public Table<T> joinIfNecessary()
        When called this will check to see if joinIfNecessary has already been invoked, and if it has it will use the previously created Table created from invoking that join. If not, it will use the base Query or Table to join off of using the specificed ILinkPropertyInfo. If a base LazyJoinTable is used it will first have its own joinIfNecessary() method invoked to make it join to its base table or query - and so on up the chain until a base Query is reached.
        Returns:
        a Table that was created using the join method on Query or Table. Subsequent calls to joinIfNecessary() on the same instance will return the previously created Table.
